Post Text: After 11 years in Corporate, I became a VP Sales.What did I learn over the years?1: Being a great seller, doesn't make you a great Leader.It certainly helps, but leadership consists of empowering and developing talent. Your world is no longer about you, it's about your team and that requires a mindset adjustment.2: Not everyone thinks the same way as you.I work at a very high-pace and I have the desire to be the best in everything I do. Not everyone shares this mentality and as a leader, it's important to get the best out of each of your team members individually, by learning what drives them personally and professionally.3: Your job is to be effective, not liked.As a leader, your role is not to make friends. It's to empower, coach and develop your team to make them more effective in their roles. Can that mean you build and foster great relationships in the process? Absolutely. But don't confuse priorities.4: You must build connective tissue.What do I mean here? You need to be a centre point, serving your team's best interests by networking with other internal team's and departments. Nothing great is ever achieved alone, you need to be the person to truly put your team on the map.5: Spend time on your leadership principles.As a leader you will have to make hard decisions. This is never easy when you're clouded by external opinions and felt pressures. It is important to take the time to build a robust set of principles you can lean on, whenever you're looking for direction to aid with making a key decision.Keep climbing 🚀

Author: Alex Alleyne
Post Text: Ever curious about what drives success in SaaS sales? Let me give you a backstage pass to my daily routine when I was a VP Sales.My Morning Sets the ToneBefore any meeting, my day starts with meditation and a quick workout. Think of it like tuning an instrument before a big concert. It helps me focus and prepares me for the day ahead.Planning is EverythingNext up, I huddle with my team for our morning forecast meeting. We're like the coaching staff on game day, mapping out plays and strategies. The goal? Predict revenue and get everyone on the same page.Wearing Multiple HatsAfter planning, my day splits into two main parts: internal training sessions and customer meetings. Imagine being a coach in the morning and a quarterback in the afternoon. Each role is vital to winning the game and landing high-value deals.The Heart of the Job: Customer MeetingsWhen I sit down with customers, it's all about them. It's like being a detective and a problem-solver rolled into one. I listen to their needs, offer a tailored demo, and map out how our technology can solve their issues.Negotiations: The Final FrontierClosing deals is the climax, but it's not just about shaking hands and celebrating. It's about giving value for value. Think of it like trading rare football cards. Both parties should walk away feeling like winners.Why I Wouldn't Choose Any Other CareerLook, SaaS sales careers are a challenge. But the rewards? Beyond measure. At the end of the day, I feel like a maestro who's conducted a beautiful symphony—each note carefully planned and executed for maximum impact.Quick Takeaways for Aspiring Sales Leaders- Meditation and exercise kickstart my productivity.- Morning forecast meetings help align the team.- The customer-centric approach turns prospects into clients.- Negotiation is a two-way street, aiming for a win-win.Keep climbing 🚀
